title: Brainstem Involvement: Left Posterior Fossa Meningioma
chief_complaint: I have a sharp, band-like pain in my forehead when I look up or cough. My tinnitus in the left ear has been getting worse for years, and recently my hearing on that side seems worse too. I also feel unsteady and find myself drifting to the side when I walk.

problem_summary.onset: 12-year history of tinnitus; recent increase in hearing loss.
problem_summary.laterality: Left-sided auditory symptoms; drifting to one side.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Band-like sharp forehead pain (triggered by upward gaze, coughing, breath-holding), memory problems, unsteadiness.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Diagnosis of neurological and auditory symptoms.

history.present_illness: 66-year-old female presenting with a 12-year history of left-sided tinnitus that has gradually worsened. She reports a recent subjective increase in left-sided hearing loss. She experiences progressive unsteadiness and drifts to one side. She also reports sharp forehead pain associated with upward gaze, coughing, or Valsalva maneuver.
history.otologic_history: Left-sided tinnitus (12 years), recent left hearing loss, unsteadiness.
history.medical_psych_history: Subjective memory problems reported. No other major cognitive issues.
history.prior_management: None reported prior to this evaluation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild to moderate bilaterally symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Thresholds are normal in low frequencies, sloping to moderate loss in high frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition bilaterally, despite the subjective complaint of left-sided hearing loss.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR). Normal morphology for the right ear. Left ear showed abnormal absolute latency for wave V and extended I-III interwave interval. Abnormal Interaural Latency Difference (ILD).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Dichotic Digits Test. Results indicated a poorer performance in the left ear compared to the right ear.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan. Showed a 4-cm mass lesion (meningioma) in the left posterior fossa pressing against the tentorium, obliterating the fourth ventricle, and causing obstructive hydrocephalus.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with symmetrical high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss and excellent speech recognition scores, which initially contradicts her subjective complaint of left-sided hearing difficulty. However, retrocochlear testing reveals significant abnormalities on the left side. The ABR demonstrates a delayed Wave V and extended I-III interval in the left ear, and dichotic listening tasks show a left-ear deficit. These findings are consistent with the radiological confirmation of a large left posterior fossa meningioma affecting the brainstem and causing hydrocephalus.
counseling_points: Discuss that while the standard hearing test shows equal hearing, the 'processing' tests (ABR and Dichotic Digits) confirm the difficulty reported in the left ear.
Explain that the unsteadiness and specific headache triggers are likely related to the pressure the mass is placing on the brainstem and fluid pathways.
Immediate referral to neurosurgery is required given the size of the mass and obstructive hydrocephalus.
notes_for_actor: You should exhibit unsteadiness when moving, perhaps drifting slightly to one side.
Emphasize the specific triggers for your headache: looking up, coughing, or holding your breath.
While you can hear quiet sounds reasonably well (symmetrical audiogram), you feel something is 'wrong' or 'unclear' on the left side specifically, alongside the tinnitus.
